text: Patient: disappear. Doctor: We need some red blood cells and I think I can corral some. He just has to be around you to get it. Patient: Right. Patient: I don’t know if you can just write me. If you just write them, you know, that would save me a trip. Doctor: Can’t we just write them? I mean it’s just because I mean a couple of things. Doctor: So why don’t we just write them for you? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Don’t you think? Because it’s like… Patient: That’s fine by me. Doctor: You’ve got, I mean you were scattered before because you weren’t really coming here… Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure. Family Member: Aside from the fact, do we have an appointment time for September fifth? Only because I just need to know so that if I need to adjust my schedule at school, um, so. Healthcare Professional: So, September fifth, nine-thirty lab work, and ten-thirty, the visit. So the time is nine-thirty to ten-thirty. Family Member: Now, for the next, I guess, will be continue to have doctor at ten-thirty? Doctor: Not necessarily. If you wants them at K___, who’s there that day, what the schedule looks like. Do you prefer later or earlier? Family Member: Mm, I mean. Doctor: Yeah. L___ can help with scheduling. If you prefer, like an afternoon appointment, let’s say, instead of morning, or if you want to be like the very first patient that comes in. The lab I think opens at six a.m. So we have some patients that come like at six and then see that doctor. Most people don’t want to come that early.

text: Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

text: Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine. Doctor: Yeah, they won't be subtle when they decide to act tough. You're gonna feel it. It's not the occasional, Oh, that kind of hurts. It's the oh man this day hurts every day. Family Member: He has body aches, constantly, his whole body aches and I'm trying to figure out what's causing these body aches. It's like he sat there the other day and was telling me how he was feeling and I know this is terrible, but I started laughing because and I know I was not laughing at you. Yeah, I feel overwhelmed. Like there's nothing I can do. Patient: I’ve been going to a chiropractor for 15 years. Almost on a weekly basis Doctor: Yeah. Patient: To get my back adjusted. They adjust my upper back and my lower back and they adjust my neck. Family Member: But this all over body aching is how long.

text: Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin. Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there.

You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there.

text: Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel – Doctor: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time. Family Member: Poison (chuckles) Doctor: Okay? Patient: And the V___ Patient: I was seeing a doctor V___ in O____ in D____. Doctor: That’s him.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: And uh the study that we have, which we have open right now is called the Transformer Trial. It’s an acronym. You don’t need to remember that. We’ll give you information about that – to read it. Patient: I appreciate that, thanks. Doctor: It’s called the Transformer Trial because it was funded by a grant that was called the Transformative Impact Grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And so we applied for a grant at the Department of Defense, actually, DOD. And they have a program whereby they support prostate cancer studies. Patient: DOD?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
